title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why an object may feel warmer or colder when touched, even if it's at the same temperature as another object?

options.label: B
options.text: The object's material and its ability to conduct heat

multiple-choice.question: In the experiment, which object felt colder to the touch: the metal hard drive or the book?
What was used to measure the temperature of the book and the hard drive?
What was the result of measuring the temperature of the book and the hard drive?

options.label: A
options.text: The book was warmer than the hard drive

options.label: B
options.text: The hard drive was warmer than the book

options.label: C
options.text: Both were at the same temperature

multiple-choice.question: Why did the aluminium block melt the ice cube faster than the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: Because aluminium is a better insulator

options.label: B
options.text: Because aluminium is a better thermoconductor

options.label: C
options.text: Because aluminium is colder than plastic

options.label: D
options.text: Because aluminium is warmer than plastic

multiple-choice.question: What is thermoconductivity?

options.label: A
options.text: The rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of an object to insulate heat

options.label: D
options.text: The size and shape of an object

multiple-choice.question: Why did the hard drive feel colder than the book, even though they were at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the hard drive is made of metal

options.label: B
options.text: Because the book is made of paper

options.label: C
options.text: Because the hard drive conducts heat away from the hand faster

options.label: D
options.text: Because the book conducts heat towards the hand faster

multiple-choice.question: What do you actually feel when you touch an object?

options.label: C
options.text: The rate at which heat is conducted towards or away from you

multiple-choice.question: Why is it more comfortable to stand on a bath mat than on a towel after a shower in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the bath mat is warmer than the towel

options.label: B
options.text: Because the bath mat is softer than the towel

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from the body

options.label: D
options.text: Because the towel is colder than the bath mat

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concept demonstrated in the experiment with the aluminium and plastic blocks?

options.label: C
options.text: The difference between temperature and heat

options.label: D
options.text: The effect of size and shape on temperature

options.text: The modern strain was more virulent

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of the grid optical illusion in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the brain's ability to recognize faces

options.label: B
options.text: To show how the brain interprets light information

options.label: C
options.text: To test the viewer's peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: To prove the existence of magical things in images

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of retinal ganglion cells in the visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: To decrease contrast with lateral inhibition

options.label: B
options.text: To increase contrast with lateral inhibition

options.label: C
options.text: To detect only white spots in the visual field

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the edges of objects

multiple-choice.question: Why do optical illusions work even when wearing glasses or looking at a computer screen?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are a defect in the eyes

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are a result of the brain's visual system

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are caused by magical things in images

options.label: D
options.text: Because they only work on certain types of screens

multiple-choice.question: What assumption does the brain's visual cortex make about the lighting of an image?

options.label: A
options.text: That light comes from multiple sources

options.label: B
options.text: That light comes from a single source, shining down from above

options.label: C
options.text: That light comes from the sides

options.label: D
options.text: That light is not important for interpreting images

multiple-choice.question: What is the fusiform face area responsible for in the brain?
Why do we focus on the eyes and mouth when recognizing faces?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the most visible features

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are the most important for expressing emotions

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are the easiest to recognize

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the only features that matter

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the brain takes a shortcut in processing visual information?

options.label: A
options.text: It always produces an accurate representation of the world

options.label: C
options.text: It only uses assumptions about visual information

options.label: D
options.text: It never uses cognitive energy efficiently

multiple-choice.question: What is the main job of the brain's visual system, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect only white spots in the visual field

options.label: B
options.text: To increase contrast with lateral inhibition

options.label: C
options.text: To construct a world on the fly with tried and mostly true tricks

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the edges of objects

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain use assumptions about visual information?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is busy and needs to allocate cognitive energy efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: Because it only uses assumptions about visual information

options.label: D
options.text: Because it never uses cognitive energy efficiently

multiple-choice.question: What do optical illusions reveal about the brain's visual system?

options.label: C
options.text: That it constructs a world on the fly with tried and mostly true tricks

options.label: D
options.text: That it only uses assumptions about visual information

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of the Earth's surface that coral reefs occupy?
Where do most coral reef fish begin their life cycle?
What is unique about the way some baby coral reef fish larvae absorb oxygen?

options.label: A
options.text: They use gills to extract oxygen from the water

options.label: B
options.text: They absorb oxygen directly from the water through their tissue-thin skin

options.label: C
options.text: They hold their breath for long periods

options.label: D
options.text: They use air sacs to store oxygen

multiple-choice.question: What do marine biologists now believe about larval fish, contrary to previous assumptions?

options.label: A
options.text: They are passive drifters dispersed by ocean currents

options.label: B
options.text: They are capable of taking their fate in their own fins to maximize their chances of survival

options.label: C
options.text: They only use sound to navigate

options.label: D
options.text: They only use smell to navigate

multiple-choice.question: What sensory systems do larvae use to navigate when searching for their homes?

options.label: C
options.text: A complex suite of sensory systems, including sound and smell

multiple-choice.question: What allows larvae to distinguish between different environments, even adjacent reefs?
What happens when larvae find a suitable coral reef but conditions aren't right?

options.label: A
options.text: They settle down and metamorphose into adults

options.label: B
options.text: They jump back up into higher water masses and ride on

multiple-choice.question: What is the current state of knowledge regarding the geographic movements of individual larva for most species?
What do scientists now believe about the abilities of baby coral reef fish larvae?

options.label: B
options.text: They are strong swimmers and can navigate using sensory cues

options.label: C
options.text: They can only swim short distances

options.label: D
options.text: They can only navigate using sound

multiple-choice.question: What is the current state of knowledge regarding the secret lives of baby fish?
